On 8/31/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> I ran into this on a project recently, and we decided to throw away all
> the failing tests (meaning only that we removed them from the build's
> test run) and created backlog items to reintroduce those tests into the
> build. I think it's better, psychologically, to get back to 100%
> passing, then add tests and keep them passing, than it is to tolerate 5%
> failure, then try to get back down to 0% failure.
> --

That's the spirit of what and why I did what I did.

I used to exclude tests but found that there was no motivation to ever
unexclude them. Associating the test with a bug gave us the
satisfaction of a green lava lamp without having to disable the
failing test.

Kevin
